review.title: Computing the Ramsey Number R(4,3,3) using Abstraction and Symmetry breaking
review.abstract: The number $R(4,3,3)$ is often presented as the unknown Ramsey number with the best chances of being found "soon". Yet, its precise value has remained unknown for almost 50 years. This paper presents a methodology based on \emph{abstraction} and \emph{symmetry breaking} that applies to solve hard graph edge-coloring problems. The utility of this methodology is demonstrated by using it to compute the value $R(4,3,3)=30$. Along the way it is required to first compute the previously unknown set ${\cal R}(3,3,3;13)$ consisting of 78{,}892 Ramsey colorings.

metadata.title: Computing the Ramsey Number R(4,3,3) using Abstraction and Symmetry breaking

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: This paper introduces a general methodology that is applicable to graph edge coloring problems and demonstrates its application in the search for Ramsey numbers. These are notoriously hard graph staining problems that involve matching colors to the margins of a complete diagram. One (r1,.., rk; n) Ramsey staining is a graph staining in k colors of the complete diagram Kn, which is not a monochromatic complete sub-graph crystal in color i for each 1 ≤ i ≤ k. The set of all such staining is referred to as R (r1,.,.,., rk). The Ramsey number R (r1,.,., rk) is the least n > 0 such that no (r1,., rk; n) staining exists. Specifically, the number R (4, 3, 3) is often presented as the unknown Ramsey number with the best chance to be found for 50 years, yet unknown. "

sections.heading: 5 Abstraction: Degree Matrices for Graph Colorings
sections.text: The graphics sequence is a sequence that can facilitate the search for the order of degrees of some graphics. The idea underlying our approach is that if the combinatorial problem in the hand is too hard, then perhaps an abstraction of the problem will be solved. In this case, a solution to the abstract problem can be used to facilitate the search for a solution to the original problem. The graphics sequence is a graphics sequence that may solve an abstraction of the problem.

sections.heading: 9 Conclusion
sections.text: This implies that R (4, 3, 3) ≤ 30, and thus by known boundaries that R (4, 3, 3) = 30.The exact value R (4, 3, 3) has been unknown for almost 50 years. We have applied a methodology that uses SAT solving, abstraction and symmetry to calculate R (4, 3) = 30.The exact value R (4, 3, 3) is unknown. We have applied a methodology that uses SAT solving, abstraction and symmetry to calculate R (4, 3) = 30.We expect this methodology to be applied to a number of other hard graph staining problems.The question of whether a right proof is a proper proof is debatable.

In 1966 Kalbfleisch [7] reported the existence of a circulant (3, 4, 4; 29) coloring.

When searching for a graph coloring, on top of graph isomorphism, solutions are typically closed under permutations of the colors: the names of the colors do not matter and the term often used is “weak isomorphism” [12] (the equivalence relation is weaker because both node names and edge colors do not matter).

Often one first attempts to compute all the solutions of the coloring problem, and to then apply one of the available graph isomorphism tools, such as nauty [8] to select representatives of their equivalence classes modulo (weak) isomorphism.
To this end, we follow [3] where Codish et al.
show that the symmetry breaking approach of [2] holds also for graph coloring problems where the adjacency matrix consists of integer variables.
We applied an approach called k-layering described by Derrick Stolee [17].
In our implementation this is performed by the finite domain constraint compiler BEE and details can be found in [10].
The column headed by “#\≈” specifies the known (except for the last row) number of colorings modulo weak isomorphism [15].
The sets of colorings obtained with symmetry breaking have been verified to reduce, using nauty [8], to the known number of colorings modulo weak isomorphism indicated in the second column.
Degree matrices are to graph coloring problems as degree sequences [4] are to graph search problems.

We note that recently, the set R(3, 3, 3; 13) has also been computed independently by Stanislaw Radziszowski, and independently by Richard Kramer and Ivan Livinsky [14].
Most famously the issue caused much heated debate after publication of the computer proof of the Four Color Theorem [1].

The fact that at least two other groups of researchers (Stanislaw Radziszowski, and independently Richard Kramer and Ivan Livinsky) report having computed this set and quote [14] the same number of elements is reassuring.

Yet, its precise value has remained unknown for almost 50 years. This paper presents a methodology based on abstraction and symmetry breaking that applies to solve hard graph edge-coloring problems. The utility of this methodology is demonstrated by using it to compute the value R(4, 3, 3) = 30. Along the way it is required to first compute the previously unknown set R(3, 3, 3; 13) consisting of 78,892 Ramsey colorings.
